citations.narrative:
The halter on the zebu is not attached correctly and is hanging loosely around its neck. The current placement of the
halter poses a potential safety hazard to the animal if it gets caught up on fencing, or another animal. This halter needs to
be removed or attached securely to reduce this risk and for the safety of the animal.

**There are wire panels placed down on the ground in the cavy and crested porcupine enclosure that are not properly
secured or buried. This is creating a potential hazard to the animals when they dig as holes are created which could
cause them to potentially get a foot or leg caught in the panel. These sections of wire panel need to be covered to protect
the animals from injury.
**There are metal screens in the windows of the crested porcupine and kangaroo enclosures that are in disrepair and
need to be removed for the safety of the animals and to keep the enclosure in good repair.

The facility does not have a 6-foot perimeter fence around the property that can act as secondary containment for the
crested porcupine, cavy and kangaroo species. The licensee does have a 5-foot fence that is around portions of the
property and secondary entrances on all three enclosures to prevent escape when entering the enclosure for husbandry
and cleaning procedures. There is no variance on record for the 5-foot fence. When fencing is less than 6 feet, a variance
approved by the Administrator must be in place.

The shelter for the kangaroo is filled with miscellaneous tools, PVC tubes, a fan, signs, and other items that leave the
area cluttered and do not promote good housekeeping of the area. Buildings housing animals must be kept clean and in
good repair to facilitate the care of the animals. This shelter needs to be cleaned and clutter removed to reduce living
areas for pests and to promote good housekeeping practices.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within (2 ) more inspection(s) or by Dec 17, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The halter on the zebu is not attached correctly and is hanging loosely around its neck. The current placement of the 
halter poses a potential safety hazard to the animal if it gets caught up on fencing, or another animal. This halter needs to 
be removed or attached securely to reduce this risk and for the safety of the animal. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
**There are wire panels placed down on the ground in the cavy and crested porcupine enclosure that are not properly 
secured or buried. This is creating a potential hazard to the animals when they dig as holes are created which could 
cause them to potentially get a foot or leg caught in the panel. These sections of wire panel need to be covered to protect 
the animals from injury.  
 
**There are metal screens in the windows of the crested porcupine and kangaroo enclosures that are in disrepair and 
need to be removed for the safety of the animals and to keep the enclosure in good repair. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The facility does not have a 6-foot perimeter fence around the property that can act as secondary containment for the 
crested porcupine, cavy and kangaroo species. The licensee does have a 5-foot fence that is around portions of the 
property and secondary entrances on all three enclosures to prevent escape when entering the enclosure for husbandry 
and cleaning procedures. There is no variance on record for the 5-foot fence. When fencing is less than 6 feet, a variance 
approved by the Administrator must be in place. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The shelter for the kangaroo is filled with miscellaneous tools, PVC tubes, a fan, signs, and other items that leave the 
area cluttered and do not promote good housekeeping of the area. Buildings housing animals must be kept clean and in 
good repair to facilitate the care of the animals. This shelter needs to be cleaned and clutter removed to reduce living 
areas for pests and to promote good housekeeping practices.

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within (2 ) more inspection(s) or by Dec 17, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
